subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to use JUnit for multi-threaded code?
msgSnippet: ... While it is true that some problems are more likely to be visible on multi-CPU systems, which used to be fairly rare except for servers, the multi-CPU
messageBody:
j_cumps wrote:
> A tip:
> Test your multi-threaded code on a computer with more than one
> processor. Some problems with multi-threading don't show up on a
> single cpu computer.

While it is true that some problems are more likely to be visible on
multi-CPU systems, which used to be fairly rare except for servers,
the multi-CPU model is actually separate from my main concern.

I haven't kept up with all the JVM implementations, but in olden days,
a lot of JVMs would not split Java threads across separate CPUs. That
was left to multi-tasking or other platform specific implementation details.

And on systems with separate JVMs on separate CPUs, some problems
don't show up on multi-CPU systems that are real on single-JVM systems
with heavy multi-threading.

It may be that JUnit is focused on single unit tests that are executed
sequentially. I haven't see "Manning's "TDD in Action" '
so I could be wrong.
